body_html:
I think you might be right.. since I was using the stock Intel install, it was probably MKL. I went ahead and did :
pip install numpy scipy tensorflow-gpu --ignore-installed

which upgraded numpy:

% pip list | grep 'numpy\|scipy\|tensorflow\|wheel'
DEPRECATION: The default format will switch to columns in the future. You can use --format=(legacy|columns) (or define a format=(leg
acy|columns) in your pip.conf under the [list] section) to disable this warning.
numpy (1.13.1)
scipy (0.19.1)
tensorflow-gpu (1.3.0)
tensorflow-tensorboard (0.1.6)
wheel (0.30.0)

so now:

>>> np.__config__.get_info("lapack_mkl_info")
{}

And the original issue seems to be resolved. Not sure what the culprit was, but it was one of those. Thanks, can close now.

body:
I think you might be right.. since I was using the stock Intel install, it was probably MKL. I went ahead and did : 
`pip install numpy scipy tensorflow-gpu --ignore-installed`

which upgraded numpy:
```
% pip list | grep 'numpy\|scipy\|tensorflow\|wheel'
DEPRECATION: The default format will switch to columns in the future. You can use --format=(legacy|columns) (or define a format=(leg
acy|columns) in your pip.conf under the [list] section) to disable this warning.
numpy (1.13.1)
scipy (0.19.1)
tensorflow-gpu (1.3.0)
tensorflow-tensorboard (0.1.6)
wheel (0.30.0)
```
so now:
```
>>> np.__config__.get_info("lapack_mkl_info")
{}
```

And the original issue seems to be resolved. Not sure what the culprit was, but it was one of those. Thanks, can close now.
